At current price ($250) it's a steal, don't hesitate!
I recently purchased this phone on Prime Day to replace my aging Moto G power 2020
The latter was a great phone but started getting laggy over the past few months
The new 5G Ace is almost exactly the same, which is both good and bad news at the same time
The good news, like the G Power the battery lasts forever, routinely over 2 days, plus it recharges very quickly
It's also a tank, my G Power was indestructible, I probably dropped it out of my rear pocket over 100 times (with a good case) with no issues and the phone still looks brand new
That's I won't spend over $300 for a phone, I'm hard on them
Also good, the Ace comes with NFC now and wi-fi calling, which is a huge bonus since my home has marginal coverage
The bad news, if you're looking for the latest features look elsewhere
The camera is versatile and robust but not cutting edge
I'm sure there are phones that are much faster
And that durability and camera life come with a cost, the phone is heavy and big (especially with a case)
Ditch the case and it's not too bad but you're on your own if you drop it
What's the worst that can happen, the phone is only $250 right now!As for 5G, I have yet to witness the blazing speed but I'm going to blame that on my carrier and coverage in suburban Detroit
It's fast enough for what I need it for
Solid and quality built smart phone!
I read numerous reviews before making my phone purchase
Love this phone! Very much a bargain.
I was looking for a phone with a large screen to replace my Google Pixel 2XL, and this screen is even larger
I use this to stream a lot of video and also to serve as the graphical user interface for my digital audio mixer
I also like the shake feature to turn flashlight on and off
It takes great videos, selfies, macro and portrait photos
Its only shortcoming that I see is that the landscape lens on the camera does not take very clear photos and this is very evident by the lack of clarity when zooming in on subject matter
And it's 5G, so I don't have to worry about becoming obsolete and unable to connect to cell networks for many years to come

If you care about security/OS updates DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE

Right up front I must say I like my Motorola One 5G Ace though admittedly have barely begun to use its many features - I should also note that =I= don't really care too much about security and, for example, OS updates

But many people DO care about those and Motorola actually says that the One 5G Ace bought from Amazon Prime WILL NOT BE UPDATED - if you follow Motorola's Support site drilldown to find out update status, etc, for a USA Amazon Prime Ace it turns out it is not listed - selecting not listed is the results gives:
If your Android model is not listed here, it is not slated for any further Android operating system or security updates
Note that other bought-from locations like, say, Verizon say that it WILL be updated so this problem is Amazon Prime specific
Just a Heads Up - know what you're getting when you spend $300 (or more) for a phone

It was time to replace my 3 year old, unsupported, Huawei Mate SE phone, with something capable of 5G and a later version of Android
I initially bought a renewed Moptorola One 5G Ace, but battery life was not up to par, and despite being told it could be unlocked, I was unable to
So far I am happy with this phone
Transferring data from the old phone was a breeze using Android's phone-to-phone transfer mechanism, or you can use the Google backup from the cloud
PERFORMANCE - The Moto One 5G Ace uses the Qualcomm Snapdragon 750G chipset, which is not the fastest or latest out there, but it powers this phone just fine
SOFTWARE - The phone comes with Android 10, and minimal bloatware loaded, which is nice
DISPLAY - It has a nice big 6
7 2400x1080 FHD+ display which is reasonably bright
BATTERY - The One 5G Ace has a 5000 mAh battery, bigger than many phones in this class
ERGONOMICS - The phone feels good in your hand, and has a good weight to it
CAMERA - The phone has several lenses which deliver reasonable photo quality, but not to the level you would get on a more expensive phone
If you are a photographer looking to use your phone for real photography, this is not the phone for you
NETWORK - The phone supports 5GHz WiFi which is a nice to have that I did not have on my old phone
CALLS - Something many ignore on a PHONE these days, since this is what a PHONE is supposed to do
GPS - The GPS works well, locks-on rapidly, and supports tracking of multiple different GPS satellite networks, including GPS, A-GPS, GLONASS, GALLIEO, LTEPP, and SUPL
SENSORS - The phone has a Fingerprint reader, Proximity sensor, Accelerometer, Light Sensor, Gyro, e-Compass, Barometer and Near Field Chipset (NFC)
SUMMARY - In summary this phone offers good value for the price

Brand new phone Google Maps shows with 0 Bytes -- bad firmware?
I have had 5 Moto smartphones before this purchase and I have been satisfied with their price, performance, and features (minimalist Android)
My Moto X4 battery performance was deteriorating
For replacement looked at the various Moto models and decided on the Moto One 5G Ace

I was quite happy with the device until I tried to use Google Maps!It would just not launch, even though the Apps section indicated it was *installed*Upon investigation, I noticed that the storage for the Google Maps application showed 0 Bytes!That explained why the app would not launch
I have never come across an App with 0 Bytes storage being reported as Installed

Has anybody else faced this kind of anomaly with Android phones?My concern is how can this happen?Could it be because of bad internal storage, the Android firmware did not get installed properly?Lesson learned -- 1) check out the Apps on the new phone *before* spending hours transferring data from the old phone to the new phone! and 2) get a replacement as the problem could be due to bad internal storage
I'll be returning the phone back to Amazon

Motorola One 5G Ace is a great phone!
At the time of this review 08/04/2021, I got this phone for about $260 through T-Mobile
The phone comes with features more expensive phones don't now a days; like a charger, headphone jack, FM radio, and expandable storage
All areas are different, but in my local area, 5G is netting me around 300 mbps down, 7 mpbs up, ataround 30ms ping, which is plenty fast for me
The back of the phone has a good non-slippery design, although I still buy cases for all my phones regardless
Transferring my data from my previous working phone was easy and directions are automated with the initial setup
I was able to uninstall apps, like Facebook, which is a big deal to me
If you don't like the default gestures, you can change the settings to use the bottom navigation buttons
The calls are clear, which my previous phone, Pixel 3a XL, was having issues with
The Motorola One 5G Ace is a nice upgrade and I am very happy with it
